questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute gout. Glaucoma is not a known association ofacute gout.Ocular manifestations seen in acute gout are episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis. Ocular structureshave a relatively poor solvent ability, in addition to lower temperatures. Therefore, they arepredisposed to tophi deposition. As a result of urate deposits, crystal-induced inflammation of theaffected tissue is responsible for causing episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis.592

questions.question: A 10-year-old girl with neurological manifestations was referred from the pediatric OPD. Herocular examination findings is as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The image shows the Kayser-Fleisher (KF) ring, which is a characteristic finding of Wilson'sdisease.KF ring consists of the deposition of copper in the Descemet membrane of the cornea. The ringsare usually golden-brown and are visible only under the slit-lamp. They do not impair vision. They593disappear on treatment with anti-copper drugs and reappear with disease progression. They area characteristic sign of Wilson's disease but are not pathognomonic. They can also be seen in:• Primary biliary cholangitis• Primary sclerosing cholangitis• Cholestasis.Sunflower cataract is a rare finding of Wilson's disease. It occurs due to the deposition of copperin the centre of the lens. It consists of a greenish central opacity with spoke-like radial opacitiesand is visible only under the slit-lamp. questions.question: Which of the following conditions can occur as an ocular manifestation in a patient withdengue?
questions.explanation: Cataract is not an ocular manifestation of dengue.Dengue has varied manifestations, in different organ systems, mainly of inflammation andbleeding. Until recently, apart from retro-orbital pain, eye involvement was not recognized as acommon feature of dengue infection. Potential pathogenic mechanisms include a direct viral effecton the eye, an immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related todengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements.Ocular manifestations of dengue:• Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset,often around the time of the platelet nadir.•Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage.Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema,vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis595•Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs overseveral weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

questions.question: A 6-year-old girl is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. She has a large port-winestain on the right side of her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows aleptomeningeal angioma. What is the most common ocular manifestation of the underlyingcondition?588
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture of a young child presenting with unilateral port wine stain in the regionof trigeminal nerve supply and leptomeningeal angioma as seen on MRI is indicative ofSturge-Webber syndrome (SWS). Glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation of SWS.Sturge weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatoses) that is characterized byunilateral capillary malformation at the region of trigeminal supply known as port wine stain ornevus flammeus, ipsilateral diffuse cavernous hemangioma of the choroid and ipsilateralleptomeningeal hemangiomatosis, which causes seizures and mental retardation.Ocular manifestation of SWS include:•Glaucoma - most common ocular manifestation. It develops anywhere between infancy toadulthood. When developed in infancy it presents as buphthalmos.• Diffuse choroidal hemangioma• Serous retinal detachment• Visual field defects- homonymous hemianopia due to the leptomeningeal hemangiomas affectingthe optic tract or occipital lobe.•Heterochromia of the iris• Episcleral and conjunctival lesionsOption A: Uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue of the eyes. It can be associated with anumber of systemic conditions such as sarcoidosis, behcet's disease, ankylosing spondylitis,reiter's syndrome, Toxoplasmosis and Posner-Schlossman syndrome (PSS).Option B: Retinitis pigmentosa is an inherited or acquired pigmentatory retinal dystrophyaffecting the rods more. The earliest manifestation is worsening of night blindness whichgradually progresses to tunnel vision and ultimately loss of central vision. The classic triad offindings in RP comprises bone-spicule retinal pigmentation, arteriolar attenuation and waxy discpallor.Systemic Associations of RP include:• Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome• Cockayne's syndrome• Refsum's syndrome• Usher's syndrome•Bassen-Kornzweig syndromeThe below given image shows the classical triad findings of Retinitis pigmentosa.596Option C:Keratitis is the inflammation of cornea which is characterised by corneal edema, cellularinfiltration and ciliary congestion. It can be either infectious or non-infectious in nature whichincludes allergic keratitis, neurotrophic keratitis, exposure keratitis and peripheral ulcerativekeratopathies such as Rosacea keratitis and Mooren's ulcer.

questions.question: A 70-year-old man presented with complaints of diminution of vision in both eyes for the last6 - 8 months. On examination, bilateral cataracts were seen. Incidentally, you also note irispearls. Which of the following conditions should you suspect in this patient?
questions.explanation: Iris pearls are pearly-white nodules seen on the iris in leprosy.They are asymptomatic, 0.3 to 1.0 mm in diameter, dull yellowish-white in colour, and are seen atan early stage of the disease. It is not associated with any inflammatory changes in the anteriorchamber. Histologically, it consists of lepromatous bacilli packed within mononuclear cells oracid-fast material with accompanying foreign body reaction. Inside the eye, leprosy bacillipreferentially lodge in the iris and ciliary body, due to the relatively cooler temperatures and highvascularity.

What is this most likely due to?Chronic hypertensionb) Diabetesc) Sickle cell diseased) Central retinal vein occlusionClare GilbertQuestion 14:In patients with a long-standing history of Crohn's disease, which of the following ocularcomplications is the most likely to develop?
questions.explanation: The given image suggests a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.The hallmark of Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is neovascularization. Abnormal newvessel formation, which occurs on the inner (vitreous) surface of the retina and may extend intothe vitreous cavity, can cause vitreous haemorrhage. Neovascularization is often accompanied bypre-retinal fibrous tissue, which, along with the vitreous, can contract, resulting in traction retinaldetachment. In addition, tiny microaneurysms can also be seen.
